newsitem.title: USA: US lawmakers, TV execs to meet on TV ratings.
newsitem.headline: US lawmakers, TV execs to meet on TV ratings.

text.p: An influential senator critical of the television industry's new system for rating programs said Friday that lawmakers plan to meet soon with TV and Hollywood executives to discuss possible changes.
"I believe that we are now in a period of negotiation," said Sen. John McCain, an Arizona Republican who chairs the Senate Commerce Committee.

McCain told reporters after a speech to the United States Telephone Association that lawmakers and industry executives plan to sit down together soon. McCain said he wants parents groups involved in any talks.

He said the executives -- Jack Valenti of the Motion Picture Association of America and Eddie Fritts of the National Association of Broadcasters -- are striving to achieve a consensus on the ratings within the industry.
McCain said it is too early to know the final outcome.
The age-based ratings drew fire at a Commerce Committee hearing last week from lawmakers who said the current system does not go far enough.

Lawmakers from both parties contended that the industry should adopt a content-based system that spells out the level of sex, violence and strong language in a program -- a view supported by children's advocates, parents groups and others.
At the hearing, both Valenti and Fritts expressed a willingness to make changes in the system.

McCain said it was "foolish" for the industry to have adopted its aged-based system -- such as TV-14 for parents of kids under 14 strongly cautioned -- without having properly consulted with children's and parents groups first.
